title: Donald Trump's impeachment woes deepen as second whistleblower emerges over Ukraine

A second whistleblower has reportedly stepped forward over Donald Trump's alleged bid to get Ukraine to investigate his political rival Joe Biden.

Lawyer Mark Zaid, who represents the whistleblower, said they have 'direct knowledge' of the allegations, which triggered an impeachment bid against the President.

The emergence of a second protected witness, also an intelligence official, complicates efforts by Trump and his supporters to dismiss the scandal as politically motivated hearsay.

The complaint cited information received from half a dozen US officials expressing concern Trump was using his office to solicit interference from a foreign country as he seeks re-election in 2020.

(Image: REUTERS)

It also alleged Trump leveraged £324 million in aid to secure a promise from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to investigate Joe Biden and his son Hunter, who sat on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.

"I can confirm that my firm and my team represent multiple whistleblowers in connection to the underlying August 12, 2019, disclosure to the Intelligence Community Inspector General," Andrew Bakaj, a second lawyer, said on Twitter .

Zaid said the whistleblower had spoken with the inspector general as part of an initial examination of the complaint.

An interview with the inspector general gives protection the whistleblower protection against reprisals.

Even members of Trump's own party have criticised him over the row, including Republican US Senators Mitt Romney, Ben Sasse and Susan Collins.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Trump has alleged Hunter Biden profited in his business dealings in both Ukraine and China from his father's position, and that Joe Biden pushed Ukraine to fire a prosecutor to impede a probe of a company tied to his son.

There has been no evidence of any wrongdoing.

"The Biden family was PAID OFF, pure and simple!" Trump exclaimed on Twitter on Sunday.

(Image: REUTERS)

Biden spokesman Andrew Bates said Trump had "sent his administration into a tailspin by trying to bully a foreign country into spreading a comprehensively debunked conspiracy theory about the [former] vice president".

He predicted Trump would lose "the old-fashioned way: an intervention by his own country - courtesy of the American people - in 2020."

The telephone call with Zelenskiy and the whistleblower complaint prompted Democrat Nancy Pelosi to launch the impeachment inquiry on September 24.

Trump's attempts to solicit foreign interference jeopardised US election integrity and threatened national security, she said.

The investigation could lead to the approval of articles of impeachment - or formal charges - against Trump in the House.

A trial on whether to remove him from office would then be held in the US Senate.

But Republicans who control the Senate are unlikely to want to oust their leader.

(Image: REUTERS)

Democrats said any finding Trump withheld taxpayer money, already approved by Congress to help Ukraine fight Russian aggression, in exchange for a favor from Zelenskiy would strengthen the case against him.

Trump has maintained there was no "quid pro quo" in his request of the Ukrainian President, but text messages released last week have heightened Democrats' concerns.
description: The President is said to have asked his Ukrainian equivalent to investigate Joe Biden, sparking a move by rival democrats to try and remove him from office
